User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.9.2.13) Gecko/20101203 Firefox/3.6.13 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.9.2.13) Gecko/20101203 Firefox/3.6.13 I tried to download a +-400MB file from talend.com (But I think it will happen with any download that needs authentication) Because the download takes very long where I live, I only managed to download 90% of the file, and had to power down my laptop (which killed the browser). When I restarted my laptop the following day (by which time my session had expired). The browser was automatically opened again by KDE, and firefox attempted to resume the download, but the link it tried to resume produced an http error, and the download manager saw the error as an updated version of the file, and overwrote the 380MB partially downloaded file with 800kb of http error, leaving me no choice but to restart the download. (As opposed to being able to use wget -c on the partially downloaded file manually) Content of my 400MB download after download manager resumed : Access Denied
Access Denied (authentication_failed)

Your credentials could not be authenticated: "Credentials are missing.". You will not be permitted access until your credentials can be verified.

Click here to reset your Internet password.
or
Click here to change your Internet password.

Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1.Download a very large file from talend.com 2.Half way through the download, kill the browser (Not close) 3.Start browser up after reboot/ or after original download session expired. Actual Results: Download manager does not continue the download, but sees the html error (in this case access denied) as the latest version of the file, and deletes the partially downloaded file, and replaces it with an error. Expected Results: Download manager detects that the new file version is a lot smaller than the partially downloaded file, and refuses to delete the .part file. I don't mind the rest of the behavior, it must just please not delete the .part file in this case, so that I can use wget -c to get the rest of the file. It would be great if the download manager could eventually also resume downloads properly, but for now just not deleting the .part file completely will suffice.
